title: Trap Tasks: STOP Making These Options Trading Mistakes That Destroy Your Results
text: In trading options, there's a lot of things you got to do. You got to manage risk, you got to research ideas, you got to pay attention to the market to understand where opportunities might be. And unfortunately, in all of these different things that you have to do, there is a bucket of things I refer to as trap tasks. And these are probably some of the absolute most nefarious things that catch a lot of traders. And unfortunately, more often than not, it doesn't lead to some sort of quick blow up of capital. It's something that actually happens typically speaking slower over time. So let's talk about this idea of trap tasks. As we think what we do as traders, there are a lot of fundamental activities that you need to do in order to be successful. Yet, a lot of these fundamental activities, if you do them poorly, it can be more damaging than not doing them at all. Why? Think of it this way. If you spend a lot of time doing something thinking it's helping, but it's actually hurting, but you don't know. That's problematic. A great example of this. I was stretching my hamstrings every single night for like 15 minutes without break for like two years because I thought that I just had systematically tight hamstrings. Little did I know, I actually had a herniated disc at L4L5. What's the problem there? The way that I was stretching my hamstrings was literally

So is there some sort of big edge baked into that easy to access information, maybe maybe not, but it's probably going to be less of an edge than you might want in terms of severity. Then there's also the desired outcome bias, which is when we go into something programmed with what we want to see, which then poisons all of our decision making all the way down that path. text: It's the planning exercise that's super valuable. All right, let's talk about analysis. A lot of people will say stuff like, oh, I use bow and Japan's, or I use moving averages, whatever. And very much like what we saw up in risk management, the reality is your profit mechanisms come first every single time. So what that means is when we're looking at technical analysis, fundamental analysis, those are tools designed to help you identify opportunities. They are not any sort of edge in and of themselves. So for example, a great example of this, a really, really commonly researched well-understood profit mechanism, which I have a video that goes into detail on profit mechanisms, is momentum. It's really well researched. We know it's there. It's robust. So if I want to start with the profit mechanism of momentum, then I start thinking, what kind of analysis tools might help me identify good candidates to trade momentum? Maybe that's stuff like moving averages, which measure momentum. My point here is that the signals used should directly allow us to identify and trade the profit mechanisms, not signals for the sake of signals. And one other quick note here is I cannot tell you how frequently that I come across people that will say, like, oh, normally when I use bow and Japan's, I see the stock do this when it touches the upper bow and Japan. This is the pure definition of confirmation bias. It's somebody seeing and remembering
